By ED HIRSCHMANN, Associate Editor
HOPKINS LIKES IKE, if straw votes are any indication.
In last week's Presidential Preference Poll, conducted by the
Students for Democratic Action, General Dwight Eisenhower polled
445 of the 681 votes cast, to defeat his nearest rival, Governor
Adlai Stevenson, by a nearly two-to-one margin. Stevenson was the
choice of 229 students.
Minor party candidates received almost negligible totals. Vincent
Hallinan, of the Progressive Party, received four write-in votes.
The name of Stilart Hamblen, Prohibition Party candidate, was
written on two ballots, with Socialist, Darlington Hoopes on one.

U. S. Increases Research;
Endowment Fund Up
In the past ten years, Johns Hopkins has become one of the
nation's major University centers for Government-sponsored research,
according to the Hopkins treasurer's report released last week
The University's treasurer, Henry S. Baker, also reported a net
increase of $2,982,982 during the past fiscal year swelling the total
Hopkins endowment to a current market value of $49,334,460.

Research

•

Government spending for ' research at the University last year
was nearly 40 times what it was
in 1942. During that first year of
World War II, Government contracts at Hopkins totaled only
$363,000. Last year, the Government paid $14,167,000 for research here.
Figures showing that this total
represents nearly two thirds of all
Hopkins expenditures during the
past year demonstrate the importance of government sponsored research projects.

Endowment
The endowment increase was
paralleled by a net addition of
$1,003,442, in the plant fund
which brought total assets to $20,192,225, the report stated. Government contracts accounted for
$14,167,332 of the total University income of $22,660,002.
Other sources of income were
endowment income totaling $1,725,645; $120,270, contributed by
alumni and friends during 1951,
and $1,896,759 in restricted gifts
and grants.

Established in 1950 to secure
money for an elaborate development program now under way at
both the University and Johns
Hopkins Hospital, the Johns
Hopkins Fund, a separate corporation directed by Mr. Douglas Coleman contributed $760,000 to the
University.

Blown Fuses
Upset WTHU
The failure of Radio Station
WJHU to go on the air as scheduled Thursday, October 9, Was
due to a breakdown in the station
equipment, a spokesman for the
station announced this week.
According to schedule, the
equipment should have been completed and completely tested in
time for the scheduled opening,
but certain pieces of the equipment broke down unexpectedly.
Repairing this upset the schedule,
and complete construction and
testing of the transmitter was not
possible.

It was announced Thursday by
Warren Gruppe, chairman of the
B.C. sponsored bloodmobile drive,
that Hopkins had exceeded its
quota of 120 pints of blood in the
recent blood letting that took
place in Levering Hall Wednesday.
Of the 153 students that had
made appointments to give blood
140 were accepted and 127 full
pints of blood were collected. Officials were pleased with the turnout, unusually large for so short a
publicity drive, and said that
donations were up 37 pints from
last year.

This practice started three years
ago when the Vigilantes were organized to improve public relations and to insure that all complaints from neighbors are channeled to the Committee instead of
to the local police or to the Dean
as was the former practice.
Way of a Vigilante
The IFB requires one fraternity per week to assign two of its
members to Vigilante duty. When
a complaint call comes in, one of
the men goes to the scene, and if
he decides that the complaint is
justifiable, he notifies the fratern-

ity of the complaint and requests
that they discontinue the disturbance.

091

Silence or Trial

ing

taining to the same fraternity the
Vigilante has the authority to
command the fraternity to quiet
down. If a fraternity does not
comply with the Vigilantes they
are subject to appear before the
IFB for trial at which time they
may be fined or otherwise punished as the IFB so judges.
Pete Hoffman, IFB chairman,
disclosed
.that the Vigilantes have
been called out only once this
year. "It was just a phonograph
being played too loud," said Hoffman. He further stated that the
IFB is vitally interested in seeing
that the fraternities and their
neighbors get along with a minimum of disention.

EVROLE

Due to the fact that all the publicity was already out, tentative
arrangements were made to go on
the air on an emergency basis,
technically, in order to meet the
scheduled opening date, while the
permanent equipment was being
completed and tested. The equipment was actually set up on an
experimental basis, but the technical quality obtained did not
meet the standards set up by the
station, the spokesmen said.
The station will go on the air
on 830 kc. sometime in.the very
near future. Publicity preceding
the opening will be in the form
of posters and a News-Letter
story.

must have completed his sophomore year by the time of application and must receive endorse.ment of the university,

at 500 pounds per year. In addition, scholars may receive any
educational
benefits
military
available at American universi-

to appilcants who have had 90

other Information may be obtained

in previous Rhodes Scholarship

700 Members
Sought By Y
Lncheon in Levering Hall officially opened the Y membership
drive last Friday.
The drive, an annual affair, and
the chief source of income for
the campus Y will run until Friday, October 24. A goal of 700
members has been set 'ay the drive
committee.
Captained by Ed Freeman, the
committee is composed of the
members of the freshman and
sophomore commissions. These
men will man booths in th6
dorm from 6:15 to 7 p.m., daily,
Members will also be sought
in Levering Hall from two to
four p.m. Monday, Tuesday and
Wednesday, and at noon time
Thursdays and Fridays.
Dues for a one year membership are $2.00, payable at the
time of application.
This year's goal of 700 members is 300 in excess of last year's
final turnout. The high goal is
aimed at securing Hopkins the
number one spot among university
campus Y's. Last year the Hopkins Y stood third in the East.
Freeman stated that this drive
will be the kick-off for a very
active program which Is being
planned for the coming year. This
program will include dances, chess
tournaments, ping pong tournaments, lectures, learn to dance
classes, and a number .of other
activities.

WHAT HATH THE 'NEW PLAN' WROUGHT?
During the first few days of the recent Orientation Week,
we viewed the freshman class with an attitude of reserved curiosity.
We wondered whether this group reflected any of the uniqueness of
the "New Plan." We looked to it hoping for an indication that the
Ailmissions Office had managed to keep pace with Homewood House
, and were compelled to examine the possibility that we might "indeed
be orienting a new breed of Hopkins man."
We left the question unanswered maintaining that any decisive
opinion must wait upon the evidence as it unfolds. The following
letter, received last week, is offered, as, at least, a partial indication of
the caliber of the class of '56.
We have taken the liberty of inserting pertinent quotations
,from recent News-Letter editorials wherever the need for clarification was particularly apparent.
The Editors
Pear Sirs:
We feel that your method of criticizing the "New Plan" by
your description of the Freshman Class has been a distortion of
the true situation. Because the class of 1956 is the first all "New

this New Plan, may be attracting a new type of personality to

must adjust to this change. The fraternities have no choice
but to bend with the prevailing wind ..." Reflection on Rushing,

clearly recollect being introduced
to the norms of the community of
which I was to become a member,
and among other things being told
that I would now have to live
under a system that was requested
and developed by my predecessors
some thirty years ago.
These I accepted without question as . being part of the academic
life at this University. They seemed to be traditions whose nature
removed the need for discussion.
They were agreed to and abided
by. Only after graphic illustration of one of these institutions
in that slick reprint from the
Hopkins Magazine did I begin to
ponder on a question which had
lain dormant in my mind for these
past years. What I refer to is the
Honor System.
Now, there is no doubt in my
mind that the concept of an Honor
System is good, but no one has
ever asked me whether or not I
want it, much less what I think
of it. I have merely subscribed to
an accepted institution in an accepted.. way. In retrospect, it appears that my indoctrination was
slightly one-sided. All I was ever

told was that this system came
through the request of the students some thirty years ago, that
it is independent of the Administration, and that it is operated by
and for the student body. I acknowledged the need; I understood the principle; I respected
the' tradition. Yet never have I,
the student of today, been asked
to give an opinion, though all
have insisted on my cooperation.
If I had been asked, I would
have then, as well as now, given
my complete approval to this Honor System. Yet this is not the
question in point, for I have never
even had the opportunity of V016.,
ing my• approval.
Searching inward, each of us
would find that this situation is
equally applicable. Would you find
yourself to be in complete accord?
Do you feel the system is working,
and if so, how . well? In effect
what's your opinion?
I feel that these are questione
which everyone should ask; answers which the Honor Commission should seek. Let the governed once again reaffirm their faith
in an existing and accepted institution. Let the system truly draw
its strength once again from each
of us.

Varied needs of 71 Du Pont plants pose
a host of original power problems
Heart of Du Pont's manufacturing
program is the power plant. To make
some 1200 products and productlines
the Company operates 71 plants.
Most require steam and electric
generation, water supply and treatment, heat exchangers, piping systems and related services. The designing of these power plants, their
erection and operation are all in the
handsofengineers,the great majority
being mechanical engineers.
But this is not the most interesting thing about power work here.
What challenges the highest skills of
the engineer at Du Pont is the wealth
of original problems constantly arising. Power requirements vary enormously,not only from plant to plant
but from time to time.
Process operating pressures may
range from over 15,000 psi. to 2 mm
of mercury, electrical requirements

Official Ring For J.H.U.

from as low as 7,000 to higher than
1 million KWH/day, and temperatures from —360° to over 3,500°F.
Here are examples of recent "offthe-beaten-path" power problems.
1. A plant using natural gas as its basic
fuel produces a waste oil of variable hydrocarbon composition and a waste gas
with only 110 Btu/cu.ft. DuPont M.E.'s
designed burners,fans, boilers and combustion controls to permit use of all
three fuels for generating steam.
2. At another plant 20,000 gpm of cooling water were to be drawn from a nearby
river. Since the water level fluctuated
40feet between normal and flood stages,
it wasnecessary to evaluate several plans
for pump-house constructions against
cooling towers. The engineers installed
a unique pump house whose submerged
vertical pumps operate even when the
structure is entirely under water.

Aside from design and construction, Du Pont mechanical engineers
concern themselves with such related
subjects as economic evaluations,
equipment selection, heat balances,
load calculations, waste heat boilers.
For example, where various process
temperatures from 300° to 600°F. were
required, Dowtherm was selected as the
supply medium at the rate of 35 million
Btu/hr.The engineers installed a central
system for primary supply because it
calculated to be more economical than
separately located vaporizers.

CARMAN'S RESTAURANT

The main object of their "reform" movement was a fellow
know more for his accomplishments in the track field—Bob
Mathias. In one of the first games of the season Mathias fumbled
five times and followed this performance the next week with two
fumbles that set up touchdowns. In a dramatic ceremony the
the defensive captain handed the captain of the offensive team a
box which was promptly handed to the decatholon champ. Inside
he found a football with a handle on it. The results were
amazing. For the next week Mathias had no trouble at all and
didn 't fumble once.
Something will probably have to be done quickly unless the
team is going to meet with disaster. This week the squad will
once again take to the road this time headed for HampdenSydney, Virginia. Although the Tigers have lost Clancy Holland,
captain of last year's team and leading ground gainer, the squad
still seems to be a strong one, winning their first three out of four
games. The most noteworthy of these was a victory over Emory
and Henry, one of the most powerful small teams in the nation
last year and Little Six champs.
The game probably will hinge on passing which so far has
been the Jay weakness both offensively and defensively. Two late
passes scored twice for F&M after the interception of a pass
started the Diplomats drive to their first score. Last week seven
Hopkins passes were intercepted. Hampden-Sydney will field a
fast veteran pass defense that should give Maestro Bucky Myers a
little trouble although an inexperienced offensive backfield should
be the weakest pass offense that the Jays have faced this year.
In conclusion, I have these words of Shelby's for all discouraged lacrosse fans. "If winter comes, can spring be far behind."

Endowment Fund Up
In the past ten years, Johns Hopkins has become one of the
nation's major University centers for Government-sponsored research,
according to the Hopkins treasurer's report released last week
The University's treasurer, Henry S. Baker, also reported a net
increase of $2,982,982 during the past fiscal year swelling the total
Hopkins endowment to a current market value of $49,334,460.

Research

•

Government spending for ' research at the University last year
was nearly 40 times what it was
in 1942. During that first year of
World War II, Government contracts at Hopkins totaled only
$363,000. Last year, the Government paid $14,167,000 for research here.
Figures showing that this total
represents nearly two thirds of all
Hopkins expenditures during the
past year demonstrate the importance of government sponsored research projects.

Endowment
The endowment increase was
paralleled by a net addition of
$1,003,442, in the plant fund
which brought total assets to $20,192,225, the report stated. Government contracts accounted for
$14,167,332 of the total University income of $22,660,002.
Other sources of income were
endowment income totaling $1,725,645; $120,270, contributed by
alumni and friends during 1951,
and $1,896,759 in restricted gifts
and grants.

Blown Fuses
Upset WTHU
The failure of Radio Station
WJHU to go on the air as scheduled Thursday, October 9, Was
due to a breakdown in the station
equipment, a spokesman for the
station announced this week.
According to schedule, the
equipment should have been completed and completely tested in
time for the scheduled opening,
but certain pieces of the equipment broke down unexpectedly.
Repairing this upset the schedule,
and complete construction and
testing of the transmitter was not
possible.

It was announced Thursday by
Warren Gruppe, chairman of the
B.C. sponsored bloodmobile drive,
that Hopkins had exceeded its
quota of 120 pints of blood in the
recent blood letting that took
place in Levering Hall Wednesday.
Of the 153 students that had
made appointments to give blood
140 were accepted and 127 full
pints of blood were collected. Officials were pleased with the turnout, unusually large for so short a
publicity drive, and said that
donations were up 37 pints from
last year.

This practice started three years
ago when the Vigilantes were organized to improve public relations and to insure that all complaints from neighbors are channeled to the Committee instead of
to the local police or to the Dean
as was the former practice.
Way of a Vigilante
The IFB requires one fraternity per week to assign two of its
members to Vigilante duty. When
a complaint call comes in, one of
the men goes to the scene, and if
he decides that the complaint is
justifiable, he notifies the fratern-

ity of the complaint and requests
that they discontinue the disturbance.

command the fraternity to quiet

are subject to appear before the
IFB for trial at which time they
may be fined or otherwise punished as the IFB so judges.

aimed at securing Hopkins the
number one spot among university

WHAT HATH THE 'NEW PLAN' WROUGHT?
During the first few days of the recent Orientation Week,
we viewed the freshman class with an attitude of reserved curiosity.
We wondered whether this group reflected any of the uniqueness of
the "New Plan." We looked to it hoping for an indication that the
Ailmissions Office had managed to keep pace with Homewood House
, and were compelled to examine the possibility that we might "indeed
be orienting a new breed of Hopkins man."
We left the question unanswered maintaining that any decisive
opinion must wait upon the evidence as it unfolds. The following
letter, received last week, is offered, as, at least, a partial indication of
the caliber of the class of '56.
We have taken the liberty of inserting pertinent quotations
,from recent News-Letter editorials wherever the need for clarification was particularly apparent.
The Editors
Pear Sirs:
We feel that your method of criticizing the "New Plan" by
your description of the Freshman Class has been a distortion of
the true situation. Because the class of 1956 is the first all "New
Plan" class, it should be evident that no final conclusins can be
drawn now.
.. We may indeed be orienting a new breed of Hopkins
man, but we are not yet convinced that this is so. The indications
have been too few and the time for analysis much too short.
We shall cross our legs and make ready to observe the evidence
as it unfords, gathering questions and seeking answers ..."
Some Advice, A Few Impressions, Sept. 25.
You have implied in your editorials that in the freshman class
there is a large percentage of "violinists" and people who,are opposed
to fraternities and all other phases of campus social life, and that this
is an effect of the "New Plan."
"... We do not mean to imply that a definite swing away
from fraternities is developing in the freshman class as a
result of some obscure New Plan influence. We are suggesting,
however, that this translation of an ideal into efficient terms,
this new system with which we are still acquainting ourselves
this New Plan, may be attracting a new type of personality to
Homewood.
"If, during the next few weeks, the fraternities find that
they are meeting fewer party boys and more violinists, they
must adjust to this change. The fraternities have no choice
but to bend with the prevailing wind ..." Reflection on Rushing,
Oct. 2.

clearly recollect being introduced
to the norms of the community of
which I was to become a member,
and among other things being told
that I would now have to live
under a system that was requested
and developed by my predecessors
some thirty years ago.
These I accepted without question as . being part of the academic
life at this University. They seemed to be traditions whose nature
removed the need for discussion.
They were agreed to and abided
by. Only after graphic illustration of one of these institutions
in that slick reprint from the
Hopkins Magazine did I begin to
ponder on a question which had
lain dormant in my mind for these
past years. What I refer to is the
Honor System.
Now, there is no doubt in my
mind that the concept of an Honor
System is good, but no one has
ever asked me whether or not I
want it, much less what I think
of it. I have merely subscribed to
an accepted institution in an accepted.. way. In retrospect, it appears that my indoctrination was
slightly one-sided. All I was ever

told was that this system came
through the request of the students some thirty years ago, that
it is independent of the Administration, and that it is operated by
and for the student body. I acknowledged the need; I understood the principle; I respected
the' tradition. Yet never have I,
the student of today, been asked
to give an opinion, though all
have insisted on my cooperation.
If I had been asked, I would
have then, as well as now, given
my complete approval to this Honor System. Yet this is not the
question in point, for I have never
even had the opportunity of V016.,
ing my• approval.
Searching inward, each of us
would find that this situation is
equally applicable. Would you find
yourself to be in complete accord?
Do you feel the system is working,
and if so, how . well? In effect
what's your opinion?
I feel that these are questione
which everyone should ask; answers which the Honor Commission should seek. Let the governed once again reaffirm their faith
in an existing and accepted institution. Let the system truly draw
its strength once again from each
of us.

Varied needs of 71 Du Pont plants pose
a host of original power problems
Heart of Du Pont's manufacturing
program is the power plant. To make
some 1200 products and productlines
the Company operates 71 plants.
Most require steam and electric
generation, water supply and treatment, heat exchangers, piping systems and related services. The designing of these power plants, their
erection and operation are all in the
handsofengineers,the great majority
being mechanical engineers.
But this is not the most interesting thing about power work here.
What challenges the highest skills of
the engineer at Du Pont is the wealth
of original problems constantly arising. Power requirements vary enormously,not only from plant to plant
but from time to time.
Process operating pressures may
range from over 15,000 psi. to 2 mm
of mercury, electrical requirements

Official Ring For J.H.U.

from as low as 7,000 to higher than
1 million KWH/day, and temperatures from —360° to over 3,500°F.
Here are examples of recent "offthe-beaten-path" power problems.
1. A plant using natural gas as its basic
fuel produces a waste oil of variable hydrocarbon composition and a waste gas
with only 110 Btu/cu.ft. DuPont M.E.'s
designed burners,fans, boilers and combustion controls to permit use of all
three fuels for generating steam.
2. At another plant 20,000 gpm of cooling water were to be drawn from a nearby
river. Since the water level fluctuated
40feet between normal and flood stages,
it wasnecessary to evaluate several plans
for pump-house constructions against
cooling towers. The engineers installed
a unique pump house whose submerged
vertical pumps operate even when the
structure is entirely under water.

Aside from design and construction, Du Pont mechanical engineers
concern themselves with such related
subjects as economic evaluations,
equipment selection, heat balances,
load calculations, waste heat boilers.
For example, where various process
temperatures from 300° to 600°F. were
required, Dowtherm was selected as the
supply medium at the rate of 35 million
Btu/hr.The engineers installed a central
system for primary supply because it
calculated to be more economical than
separately located vaporizers.

CARMAN'S RESTAURANT

The main object of their "reform" movement was a fellow
know more for his accomplishments in the track field—Bob
Mathias. In one of the first games of the season Mathias fumbled
five times and followed this performance the next week with two
fumbles that set up touchdowns. In a dramatic ceremony the
the defensive captain handed the captain of the offensive team a
box which was promptly handed to the decatholon champ. Inside
he found a football with a handle on it. The results were
amazing. For the next week Mathias had no trouble at all and
didn 't fumble once.
Something will probably have to be done quickly unless the
team is going to meet with disaster. This week the squad will
once again take to the road this time headed for HampdenSydney, Virginia. Although the Tigers have lost Clancy Holland,
captain of last year's team and leading ground gainer, the squad
still seems to be a strong one, winning their first three out of four
games. The most noteworthy of these was a victory over Emory
and Henry, one of the most powerful small teams in the nation
last year and Little Six champs.
The game probably will hinge on passing which so far has
been the Jay weakness both offensively and defensively. Two late
passes scored twice for F&M after the interception of a pass
started the Diplomats drive to their first score. Last week seven
Hopkins passes were intercepted. Hampden-Sydney will field a
fast veteran pass defense that should give Maestro Bucky Myers a
little trouble although an inexperienced offensive backfield should
be the weakest pass offense that the Jays have faced this year.
In conclusion, I have these words of Shelby's for all discouraged lacrosse fans. "If winter comes, can spring be far behind."
